Class WordAnalysis

java.lang.Object
  WordAnalysis

public class WordAnalysis
extends java.lang.Object

Reads in a text file and analyzes the frequency of the words. Note to students: you need to add code and methods to the class to complete the project.

Version:
February 6, 2012, March 3, 2016 clarified documentation
Author:
Susan King

Constructor Summary
WordAnalysis(java.lang.String fileName)
          Creates a list of words from a file and frequency of use

Constructor Detail

WordAnalysis

public WordAnalysis(java.lang.String fileName)
             throws java.io.IOException
Creates a list of words from a file and frequency of use

Throws:
java.io.IOException - file is not found
Parameters:
fileName - the name of the text of the book
Method Detail

findWord

public int findWord(java.lang.String txt)
Finds the parameter "txt" in the words list and returns the index at which it is found. If txt is not in the words list, -1 is returned.

Parameters:
txt - the word to be found in words list or added to words
Returns:
the index in which txt was found in words list. If txt is not in the words list, -1 is returned.

getNumberOfUniqueWords

public int getNumberOfUniqueWords()
Returns how many different words are in the original file that was read in. I.e., the number of words in the original file, excluding repetitions. To state it another way, each word in the list counts exactly once, regardless of its frequency.

Returns:
the total number of different words that are in the document.

getWordQuotient

public double getWordQuotient(int num)
Determines the proportion of the specified top number of words in the "words" list divided by the total number of words in the text. Here are two examples using the book "The Tale of Peter Rabbit," which has 959 total words: If the two most frequent words are "the", which appears 47 times, and "and", which appears 44 times. In this case, getWordQuotient(2) returns 0.094890... Alphabetically, the first two words in words are: "a", which appears 28 times, and "about", which appears 2 times. In this case, getWordQuotient(2) returns 0.031282... Hence the organization of the list (whether ordered lexicographically or by frequency) affects this outcome.

Parameters:
num - the number of words which are to be used to create the ratio. The number indicates the first "num" positions in the words list.
Returns:
the quotient as described in the summary

print

public void print()
Prints out all the words in the words list. Note: the organization of the list (ordered alphabetically or by frequency) effects what is printed.

printTopWords

public void printTopWords(int x)
Prints out the first "x" number of words in the words list. Note: the organization of the list (ordered lexicographically or by frequency) affects what is printed.

Parameters:
x - the number of words to be printed from words list

printWord

public void printWord(int index)
Prints the word at a particular position in the words list.

Parameters:
index - the position of interest in the words list

sortWords

public void sortWords()
Sorts the words alphabetically.

sumTopWords

public long sumTopWords(int number)
Determines how many times the top number of words in "words" list have appeared in the original document. Note: the organization of the list (ordered alphabetically or by frequency) affects this outcome.

Parameters:
number - the number of words which are to be used to generate the sum. The "number" indicates the first "number" positions in the words list.
Returns:
the how many times the top "number" words occurs

sumWords

public long sumWords()
Determines how many words, in total, are in the original file that was read in.

Returns:
the total number of words that are in the original document; in other words, the total frequency of the words in "words" list
